This discussion poses an interesting dilemma for sources such as this. On the one hand, the kind of "Singular Intimacy" of these "Medical Stories from the Front Lines of DIsease" requires some measure of credibility. In other words, they need to be "true and real". On the other hand, these stories need to avoid identifying the subject (as, let's say, a park ranger from Brooklyn with colon cancer, who speaks with lots of grammatical errors and wears a Yankees hat). These stories also need soame measure of deniability; "we've not told you the whole story in the interest of patient confidentiality". I addition, in the words of response #58 the story needs to be sculpted "for literary style and to hold to the reader's interest".

So where does this leave readers? Wherever the writer leads them. So, color me stupid, I am perfectly happy assuming that Dr. Ofri's clinical vignette evolved as written. If it were fiction, why would her fiction stray from her own clinical opinions and standards? But if this clinical anecdote IS fiction, what separates Dr. Ofri from James Frey in "A Million Little Pieces"?

So what it is it this?. Medical fiction that is immune to clinical criticism? Or "real-life" clinical drama where the reader forever lacks the "you weren't there" element, which insulates the writer from negative feedback? Y'all can't have it both ways.

Here's the thing: Screening only shows whether or not something exists. Screening by itself does not "save lives." If a person gets screened for something, what matters is how the information is interpreted and what is done or not done based on that interpretation. If a person does not get screened, what matters is how they and their health provider of choice interpret and act upon all the information we call "health."

I do not think any of the tests for prostate cancer are 100%, and when your diagnosis is that you should have the prostate removed, I believe a second opinion is in order. We are lucky in NYC to have a great cancer hospital like Memorial Sloan-Kettering, so when my first doctor strongly urged me to make a quick decision to have my prostate removed, the doctors at Sloan did a second and more comprehensive biopsy and a cat scan, and it was determined I did not have any cancer at all. So, when the news is bad, take a breath, and take control of your situation.

While agree this is a ridiculous story, I actually think it is great media awareness around debunking pregnancy myths.  I work on a research study about prenatal care, and most women do no exercise during pregnancy, some think that it is harmful.  One woman I was interviewing today actually changed her answer to a T/F question about whether or not it is harmful to exercise because "the woman who ran the marathon did it, so it must be OK".  I think more women in America should exercise, and especially if you are pregnant so you can maintain high endorphins, good energy, and reduce excessive weight gain (in moderation of course... a marathon is definitely a little much).  Anyway...good to see some awareness about exercise during pregnancy.  Congrats to mom and baby!!

As we know each person's case is individual. For me Mona (comment #21) hit it on the head. I went from a few years of PSA 8 with much antibiotics to stop prostatatis, but no change and finally a non-specific biopsy (Mayo Clinic review). With a different doctor and no PSAs, 20 months later it was 19 (at a free screening) and a Gleason of 7, but still negative DRE. Velocity counts! Following Prostatectomy radiation PSA was down to less than 0.1, with minimal side effects.
As a long time runner I have seen Dr Fries's long term Stanford Runners study showing all diseases/conditions significantly reduced by long term running except Prostate Cancer! The medical profession would rather give a runner with low TC/HDL levels & CRPs, expensive arteriograms & statins and than read their own literature on their lack of value for this class of individuals. The medical profession needs to learn how to better individualize their patients. To complain about a cheap test like the PSA baseline and then promote other expensive unneeded testing and treatments without getting to know a patient is careless and foolish.

"One of the messages was that while cancer certainly is life-changing, it doesn’t necessarily change your life."
Well said. While I have never experienced the turmoil of cancer myself, I have read stories of those with terminal illness in "Patient Stories" by Andrea King (http://www.patientstories.com). While the experience certainly would change everything, the minutia of life (like annoyances of family members) seems decidedly stagnant.

As a primary care physician (Einstein '80, Duke '83) I've been having these discussions with patients for years - time consuming, often confusing and counter-intuitive for patients.   My own physician was aghast that I declined PSA testing (I'm 56) earlier this year (no discussion, he just included it in his orders).   Most patients opt for screening: as in court, it's easier to defend action than inaction.  And when patients opted out of testing, I experienced a momentary shudder of fear as I imagine the cross-examination: "So why exactly, doctor, when all of your colleagues were responsibly screening their patients, did you fail to deny that benefit to the plaintiff's departed spouse..."  There a chance that survival curves between screened and unscreened men will separate as we follow the cohort for 15 years just as there is a possibility that  climate change is not man-made; but we had best act on fact, not hope.  Medicine has been terribly damaged by the overselling of such hope which enriches physicians with little or no benefit to patients.  Don't hold your breath waiting for hospitals to shelve their DaVinci robotics:  those are very hunrgy machines, with some hungry urologists attached to them.  Now, let's just reflect on how the incentives are arrayed: no compensation for my discussion with my patient (lots to accomplish at the average routine health maintenance exam), versus substantial rewards to biopsy then prostatectomize your basic T1 Gleason 3+3....why is it we do what we do?  The data the USPSTF commented on has been common knowledge for quite some time.  Finally: cover for doing the right thing!

Summarizing a multi-year process, PSA test indicated biopsy; 3rd biopsy (over 2 years) found cancer.  My decision: get it out of me.  Radiation follow up after one year.  Now, 4 years further on, incontinence at the level of occasional minor annoyance.  Insignificant erectile issues (chemical aids not necessary).  Would I do the same thing today?  Yes.
I don't think it was so much fun for the kid.  Selfish of the mother.

The comments are more intriguing than the article, for this reason. The opponents of US policy (Middle East and Israel) are waiting for the US to retract.
They understand our fatigue with Iraq and Afghanistan. They also must be gauging the Obama administration for whether a soft response will register. There is calculation here. Those who believe this is a rogue element should explain because the only rogue elements in Iranian culture these days are those who feel repressed (for good reason) by totalitarian authorities. Did that disorganized lot do it? Those who have power in Iran have it because they obey. Rogue Iranian elements seem a stretch.
But what stance does the United States take when an Ambassador is threatened on our soil? Don't you want the world to know? Don't you want many countries denouncing it publically? Or do you want to signal to the Iranians that we are tired, have no cards to play, and will fold if the stakes are high?
I think we need more good poker players in this country and a better American voice to the world. It is too easy to divide us over serious issues that warrant a firm, unified response. Does American really have a choice about being a world leader?

I am glad this was stopped, if true. However, the outrage is over the top. A series of people were killed by bombings in Tehran, by our side, and we have been bragging about it. This just shows how wrong that was, since they are both the same thing, except this was only a plan, and that was a series of bombing murders in their capital.

How can people so pleased to be doing it to them be so outraged if they tried to return exactly the same?

This example of hypocrisy strongly suggests blow back. That is not an occasion for us to pound our chests and act offended. We look like fools.

I was diagnosed with Prostate cancer because the uroligist felt anodule in the digital rectal exam. My PSA was over 3, but the biopsy revealed a gleason score of 7. I had the the robotic surgery to remove the prostate in 2007 and I am not impotent(i enjoy sex) but have slight incontinence(I wear Mens Guards by Depends). I think I would be dead now if I didn't have the surgery.
Definitely an individual case-by-case kind of thing. Congratulations to her!

Actually, raw vegetables and fruits are the very best. Cooking drastically reduces the nutritional value of these foods. Grains and cooked starches are not good. They are just paste that fouls up your system. Raw nuts are a good source for a concentrated protein in moderation.

Animal products of any kind, including sea food, eggs and dairy being concentrated proteins are bad too as they putrefy in the digestive tract, contributing to all sorts of problems. Humans do not have the digestive system for these foods!

But, people are going to eat what they like and generally way too much of it. Just realize that the food industry is enormous and is pushing people to eat for fun and pleasure.

Thanks for your response. The question is not whether one has academic qualifications in Economics, the question is whether one is aware of the relevant economic issues. Talking about land acquisition (what has that to do with liberalization?), there is a certain way economists approach this problem. (and economists have very important things to say about such issues). My point was not that you should blindly trust someone's academic qualifications, but you need to be aware of what economists know about this (otherwise you can never understand or critically analyze their opinions).

I don't think Rs 5000 is enough - I think Rs 50000 is needed for a family of 5. Can the Indian government give people that money? In a poor country like India, can the government guarantee everyone a certain standard of living? Did the currently rich countries grow rich through such measures?

I've got news for you: We all have cancers of some sort. The question is whether a cancer will become life-threatening. Apparently prostate cancers rarely do. In this and other cases, the attitude of "Agh! I have a cancer -- get it out!!!" is more of a threat to your well-being than the cancer itself.

If you want to avoid/beat cancer look to your own health maintenance. If you rely instead upon a doctor's scalpel, radiation or chemical treatment, your outlook is none too good.

Where is India's Steve Jobs is a bit like asking where is America's Muhammad Yunus? Jobs could not have innovated microfinance and Yunus could not have innovated the iPad. Yet both are larger than life, inspirational figures for budding technology and social innovators.

There is one big difference, however. Jobs thrived in a mature ecosystem for technology and market-based innovations -- Silicon Valley. Yunus had to struggle against the grain of a policy ecosystem that, in many developing countries, could hardly be said to be ready for social innovations.

Where is the Silicon Valley of policy that can sniff out and invest in social innovations?

Wait a minute! Because many doctors are in a rush to do aggressive therapy that often is unwarranted, we should abandon an easy diagnostic test?
This logic is why this country in rapidly on the decline. Does anyone have any common sense anymore? Re-educate the medical community; do not punish patients.

It has been enriching to see different viewpoints from various quarters. I wish we had a little more participation from people inside India (7 of 31 makes only 23% - why did mother say I had no brain for statistics?). I am particularly thankful to NYT for providing this forum. I hope this was NOT just a storm in a teapot (coffee).Those who took the time to write must genuinely care about this subject (including "endangered" - though he/she don't have to feel so; India & America may find themselves joined at the hips into the next century. This is quite important for us all).

With general elections coming up in India, "globalization" is likely to become a campaign issue. If neither Congress nor BJP gets enough votes to form absolute majority, they may be forced into unholy coalitions. And we have already seen what may happen in such coalitions - a few years ago, CPM almost sunk the Nuclear Cooperation Treaty between India & US. I am not expressing any view whether it would have been better or worse; I am simply stating that even a small coalition member, when spirited enough, may force the majority to deviate from its policies.

If a pro-globalization party alligns with an anti-globalization party, the fate of India's market reform may be seriously affected - also causing an impact on US economy. This is NOT just idle talk; for the sake of argument, assume that as its potential future competitor in world economy, a foreign country wishes to (justifiably, in its own national interest) exert political influences over the direction of India's economic growth. It may then try to accomplish that through a political party sympathetic to its causes.

So those of us who have shown an interest in this serious topic, should contribute more; not just by offering theoratical opinions in NYT blogs, but by tangibly facilitating the success of our chosen political parties while remaining within the bounds of Indian election laws.
